claims.claim: Intratumoral SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination sensitizes tumors to anti-PD-L1 checkpoint blockade in murine models.

evidence.quote: Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: Findings in mouse models may not translate to all human tumors.

claims.claim: A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I after vaccination, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

evidence.quote: A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.
Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination

claims.caveat: Antigen presentation changes are shown in mice and may vary by tumor type.

claims.claim: Retrospective human analysis associates prior mRNA vaccination with better survival under ICI treatment.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment
Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

claims.caveat: The analysis is retrospective and likely confounded, limiting causal claims.

claims.claim: Blocking type I interferon signaling eliminates the sensitization benefit seen with mRNA vaccination.

evidence.quote: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: The mechanistic chain is described in specific models and may differ in other settings.
